the boxes on the right are: - [keysight PXI Chassis]( https://keysight.com/us/en/products/modular/pxi-products/pxi-chassis-and-controllers.html) with probably a few signal generators / VNA / digitizer - QBLOX [Cluster Series Mainf rame Synchronized Qubit Control / Readout]( https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/653289e64ff83c71222f6bf2/67124d53dab6f91526c36512_QBLOX_PRODUCTSHEET_CLUSTER-MAINFRAME_V1_7.pdf) - Zurich Instruments [SHFQC Qubit Controller]( https://zhinst.com/ch/en/products/shfqc-qubit-controller) - Quantum Machines [OPX1000: Modular High-Density Hybrid Control Platform]( https://quantum-machines.co/products/opx1000/) picture on the left is from ( https://linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7389021474457620481/)

found a materials terminology knowledge graph. the website is kind of slow though (esp. the search), and not that exhaustive.

work led by USTB. Zhang2024: [A materials terminology knowledge graph automatically constructed from text corpus]( https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-024-03448-0) They cited a lot of other relevant and similar such as [Elementary Multiperspective Material Ontology (EMMO)]( https://github.com/emmo-repo/EMMO) and [Battery Interface Ontology (BattINFO)]( https://github.com/BIG-MAP/BattINFO). Their website: [MGED-KG system]( https://mged.nmdms.ustb.edu.cn/MGEDKG/)
The corpus and ontology repository are accessible at [Zenodo]( https://zenodo.org/records/11315713) ( i havent checked whats in there )
thats a figure for their paper, they have a website, as well as sql files on zenodo

i thought general purpose LLMs are already quite good at geoguessing, specialized models are way better and blows gemini away for high accuracy. 200 m over a continent is creepy, that's ~1e-8 fractional area. the model is not just bruteforce image search/retrieval, because there would be too many images (>100 M), and they have to build a database of image embedding which combines a few existing methods. the ultimate guess is from a similarity argmax, i wonder if it could do better by e.g. weighting the coordinates of top three candidates.
Lindenberger2025: [Scaling Image Geo-Localization to Continent Level]( https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.26795)

this 0.3 mm x 0.1 mm chip from Cornell could actually go into your vaccine (it's sitting on a grain of salt). it's untethered & powered by photovoltaic, the same AlGaAs diode used for PV also acts as an LED and emits pulses that encode electrophysiological signals. ( the video is multiphoton microscopy imaging of the chip in a mouse brain )

TIL people stack diode lasers as high power pump lasers since the pump does not need to be coherent, and you can get to kilowatts to tens of kW. (left from FBH and right from TRUMPF)

[Laser Modules with High Power & Efficiency]( https://www.fbh-berlin.de/en/research/photonics/diode-laser-uv-led-modules/high-power-efficiency) Barnowski2024: [Advances in manufacturing technology for low cost QCW diode laser stacks suitable for high energy pumping applications]( https://doi.org/10.1117/12.3003308)

https://x.com/styropyro_

what people do to fibers to get fancy structures always exceeds my expectation. here is how you can get a bubble as a Fabry-Perot cavity *inside* a fiber with these four "simple" steps: 1. introduce periodic hollow damage centers in one fiber using catastrophic self-propelled self-focusing fuse effect 2. cleave it near the damage center, and splice with another good fiber, which blows up the damage into a drop shape cavity 3. cleave the spliced fiber again under microscope so that you could control where the cleaving is. The location affects the final cavity shape 4. splice it again with another good fiber and it will form a more symmetric looking cavity... the micro cavity size can be increased by shocking it again with the splicing arc..

transmission sucks but hey look how fun it is D√≠az2018: [A cost-effective edge-filter based FBG interrogator using catastrophic fuse effect micro-cavity interferometers]( https://doi.org/10.1016/j.measurement.2018.03.067)

this is really glass blowing but inside a fiber. you only need ~ 3 W to form these catastrophic fiber fuse effect periodic hollow voids, and they moves towards the optical signal source at ~ 0.5 m/s. Antunes2014: [Optical Fiber Microcavity Strain Sensors Produced by the Catastrophic Fuse Effect]( https://doi.org/10.1109/LPT.2013.2288930)

the effect itself is as old as from 1987, with very detailed description of the procedure. they tested it in as long as 1.5 km of SMF. Kashyap1988: [Observation of catastrophic self-propelled self-focusing in optical fibres]( https://doi.org/10.1049/el:19880032)

the pitch seems too big for it. Maybe if you play with the params and see if you could shrink it. also the index contrast is so strong there's going to be quite some scattering loss at the beginning and end of the array
probably proportional to how expensive your cleaver and splicer is
